physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It features a dense design of silhouttes of elephants and deers amidst trees and tendrils. The motifs are set against a cream background with the motifs being painted black and outlined in brown. There is a signature at the top-left of the batik. A vine of leaves line the sides of the batik kain panjang.
sgcool_label_text: Elephants and deers are depicted amidst trees and and tendrils on this entire kain panjang.  Set again a cream ground, the motifs are shown in indigo blue although they are outlined in soga brown, a colour that is commonly associated with central Javanese batiks.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Hendromartono’s Batik Art” Unique Pekalongan Ind”.
subject_terms_2: Batik Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs
